Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen so today i am finally 
going to make a much requested recipe crispy

pork belly which in thai is called moo grob 
so moo is pork and grob as you can probably

tell by the way it sounds means crispy so 
in thailand mugrap is actually typically

deep fried which we're not going to do today 
i got one better for you we're just going to

roast it and it's going to come out even 
better if you ask me so if you search the

internet you are going to find a lot a lot of 
different methods of creating crispy pork belly

some of which are i think unnecessarily 
complicated so i have what i have for you today is

what i've distilled down to just the bare 
essentials of what you need to do plus the actual

principles of how this works so you understand 
what you're doing and you're going to have success

with it all right let's get started so important 
thing number one that a lot of recipes will not

talk about is choosing the pork belly which 
actually has quite an impact on your recipe

when you go buy pork belly i recommend going to an 
actual butcher rather than trying to buy whatever

pieces are available at the grocery store because 
the evenness of your pork is very important so

what you see here is my pork belly jigsaw puzzle 
the missing piece is the one that i removed to

prepare for today's shoot but you can visualize so 
the whole belly is like this big right when you go

to the butcher ask for the center cut because the 
center cut will have the most even distribution of

fat you want as even and straight lines of fat and 
meat as possible it will give you the best result

the edges of the pork belly whichever edge you 
look at is going to have more fat and not as

much meat and when you bake it it's going to 
like pucker up funny and then it's going to be

like a mouthful of just fat it's not good so when 
i bought this piece it was a rectangle like this

what i then did was trim off the ends that are not 
usable so this one obviously there's like a chunk

of skin missing you want to trim that off and then 
if you see here as well look how uneven same here

on the other side okay so that's trimmed off and 
then i'm left with a more reasonable piece which

i could have cooked this whole piece but it's too 
much so i divided it in this manner and i divided

it so that the piece that i'm using is actually 
the center of the center because that's the best

with the trimmings that have uneven fat those 
are good for stews like long simmering stews i'll

link to a couple of recipes down below where it's 
not quite as important that the piece is nice and

flat and straight okay so the first thing we're 
going to do is we're going to poke tons and tons

and tons of holes in the pork skin and that's 
important because it's going to break down the

skin and allow it to puff into those little crispy 
bubbles that you want if you don't poke the skin

the pork will still be crispy but it's not going 
to be puffy you know what i mean and the puffy is

kind of what we're going for so what i like to use 
is this which is a meat tenderizer it's got lots

of sharp needles right here and it and i love it 
for a couple things it's sharp and there's lots of

needles so you're not spending 10 minutes poking 
individual holes with a skewer the other thing is

you cannot go too deep with it like because the 
your force is spread over such a large amount

and you don't want to go too deep because if you 
poke the meat the juices from the pork will flow

up while you roast it and then it'll soak out the 
skin you can also use wooden skewers which i've

used before but you want to make sure they are the 
thick big skewers not the thin little ones because

that'll break i've also used a paring knife like 
a little knife with a sharp tip but you want to

be really careful with that because that's really 
sharp and it's a single point so it's really easy

to go too deep with that you cannot use a fork 
because this is raw raw pork skin is really tough

you might have seen other recipes that use a 
fork but that's because they have cooked the skin

so some recipes will ask you to boil the 
pork in advance to fully cook it the skin

becomes soft and you can fork it i find the 
boiling an unnecessarily complicated step

so we're not gonna boil that today but if you're 
gonna do the boiling then you can use a fork and

now all you have to do is just poke the heck 
out of this pork get as many holes as you can

if you're trying to be quiet because you're 
living upstairs you can also like go gentler

and just really use your body weight it 
does not look like anything is happening

but if you look really closely you can start 
to see really really tiny holes i don't think

you can see it in the camera but like you can 
you can see some here then what you want to do

this step is optional but it's nice to score 
the skin first so that when you go to serve it

you're not having to cut through a hard sheet 
of crispy pork skin and i was going to use my

big knife but i realized that this might be 
just the right job for my tiny little cleaver

i would say like one inch strip come on little 
cleaver you can do it you can do it okay forget it

yeah you just want to go through the skin 
there we go so now let's deal with the marinade

i'm going to flip the pork over another thing i 
want to point out is if you're looking at this and

you're seeing a lot of this fat or you're seeing 
that the meat is really uneven it might be worth

trimming it because like some of this that's 
not good you can just trim that out with the

marinade in thailand they actually most of the 
time just salt it with nothing in it but i like

to actually put some five spice powder which is 
the chinese style which i have uh you can buy

from the store but i also have a recipe for making 
it yourself try not to get the spices on the skin

so that the skin won't have a funny color and then 
burn actually when we go to broil the skin at the

end a touch of white pepper this is also optional 
all right now we're going to flip it onto the skin

side so now this is where i need to talk a little 
bit about the principle of crispy pork belly so

you understand what it is you're trying to do 
here um what we need to do at this point is to

dry out the skin as much as possible so that when 
we roast it and broil it the skin will puff up if

there's too much moisture in the skin it won't get 
crispy and the way to do it one we're gonna do two

things one we're gonna let it sit in the fridge 
for 24 hours uncovered okay i've seen recipes

that say 12 hours i've gone as low as 18 hours 
but to be absolutely sure 24 is guaranteed the

other thing that we're going to do is i'm going 
to salt the skin and not only will that season

the skin the salt will also draw out some moisture 
and help that drying process along you you don't

want to go heavy you want to get this you don't 
want this to get too salty but you want to be

thorough i'm going to let this sit for 20 minutes 
and then you see that the water will have come

up and out of the skin and we're going to dab it 
dry before we stick it in the fridge now you may

have seen other recipes where they do a salt crust 
like a really thick layer of salt on the pork

when the pork is roasting the idea of that is the 
same where that salt is drawing out moisture from

the skin however i find that when you do that it's 
easy to make the skin too salty especially your if

your salt is too fine the other thing is i find 
that once that salt crust dries out and it's done

its thing in the oven then it just kind of sits 
on top of the pork skin and actually prevents the

pork skin from drying out further in the oven heat 
so i think it's better to do the salting now let

the salt do its thing now and then when we put the 
pork in the oven nothing is shielding it from just

natural evaporation during the roasting process 
okay and it also doesn't waste as much salt

so there you go you can see how much liquid 
has come out this is perfect and i'm going to

dab it with a paper towel which not only will 
absorb the water but will absorb excess salt

and then any large grains of salt remaining i 
would just brush that off now that is going to go

into the fridge uncovered for 24 hours if you're 
worried about the meat drying out don't worry it's

not going to dry out that much and any drying out 
that happens will only concentrate the pork flavor

perfect this looks great i mean it doesn't

i'm just gonna dab that because it will interfere

do we're going we're going to put this under the

burn before it has a chance to crisp up okay so 
you want and it's going to be either the most the
